Corresponds to both the English present.text: The Hebrew and Aramaic participle corresponds to multiple English verb forms.

tokensOfLine.text: In English you can say "he is writing" or "he writes."
In Hebrew and Aramaic, both of these forms would be expressed with the same participle i.e. הוּא כּוֹתֵב,
Thus, when we see the word כּוֹתֵב,
, we can't be sure from the word alone if it means "he is writing" or "he writes."

Has no time.text: A word in the participle of Hebrew or Aramaic does not alone tell us what time the action happened. This is like the English word "running," which only describes an action, not when it happened. We require the context of the sentence to determine the time of the action.

In the past.text: The participle can be used in the past tense, for example הוא היה כותב,
meaning "he used to write" or "he used to be writing." If you wanted to say "he wrote," ie a one-time past event instead of an ongoing past event, you would just use the regular
, and not the "past-tense version" of the participle.

In the present.text: The participle can be used in the present tense by adding a noun before the verb, for example, הוא כותב,

In the future.text: The participle can be used in the future tense, for example, הוא יהיה כותב,
, meaning "he will be writing." If you wanted to say "he will write," ie a one-time future event, you would just use the regular
and not the "future version" of the participle.

Here, we see the Hebrew word "running" can also mean "a person who is running." Putting a ה in front of the word ie הַכּוֹתֵב would mean "the one who runs."

Describing an instance of an action.text: The participle can function as a noun describing someone or something doing the given action. For example:
Here, we see that the Hebrew word "writing" can be used as a noun, meaning "this particular instance of the act of writing."

As adjectives.text: A participle can function as an adjective, eg:
In English, "holy" is an adjective and "being holy" is a verb, but in Hebrew and Aramaic, the same participle word "קודש" would be used for both.
